newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian government wins historic budget battle.
newsitem.headline: Australian government wins historic budget battle.

text.p: A historic assault on Australia's budget deficit by conservative prime minister John Howard survived parliamentary challenge this week, promising to return the country to surplus later in the decade.

Minority parties repeatedly attempted to block measures worth more than a quarter of the A$7.2 billion (A$5.7 billion) programme, but time after time the budget bills passed on knife-edge votes with the support of two independents.
"I was hoping that about A$6 billion would survive," said a top government official.
"But it looks like we'll get almost A$7 billion."
The success means that the government should slash the underlying deficit to under A$6 billion this fiscal year (to June 30) from A$10.3 billion in 1995/96.

As the budget cuts work up to full steam next fiscal year the deficit should fall below A$2 billion in underlying terms -- that is, excluding asset sales. The year after that is supposed to produce a small surplus, the first since 1990/91.
The motivation behind the cuts is the currently popular theory in Australia that its intractably high current account deficit and interest rates stem from a shortage of savings.

If the government would stop borrowing, economists say, the country could satisfy more of its own demand for investment and the government could let the economy grow faster -- by lowering interest rates -- without fear of inflation.
"When I talk about the desirability of budget deficits being lower, I have in mind lower interest rates," Howard told reporters on Friday.
The Liberal-National government announced the budget programme soon after it won office in March, ending 13 years of Labor rule.
The election campaign had been played out under the fiction that there was nothing wrong with the budget.

Labor defied economists' forecasts and stuck by its rosy projections of surpluses to come -- and the conservatives were happy to play along, since they hardly wanted to talk about the need for cuts during an election campaign.
Then Howard and Treasurer Peter Costello took office and announced within days that the budget was a mess and they would have cut spending and hike revenue.

The problem was the upper house of parliament, the Senate, where the government was two votes short of a majority and almost all opposing senators except a solitary independent were strongly to the left of the new government.
The breakthrough came on budget day, August 20.
As Costello prepared to spell out the intricate programme that would be the largest single fiscal tightening in Australian history, a Labor senator defected.
There were now two independents -- who ended up providing the two votes that the government needed.

The independents forced some changes on the government during the budget votes this week, but officials estimated on Friday that they had cost only A$200 million or A$300 million a year, compared with annual spending of A$136 billion.
On most bills they backed the government.
Costello and Howard actually promised A$8 billion in budget savings in March.
Since the A$7.2 billion was announced in the August budget, they have refused to discuss the remaining A$800 million.
But Howard said this week that if the government got its current programme through the Senate, then he would regard that as achieving his fiscal goal.
